sen.j: 建部 綾足（たけべ あやたり、享保4年（1719年） - 安永3年3月18日 (旧暦)（1774年4月28日））は、江戸時代中期の俳人・小説家・国学者・画家。
sen.e: Ayatari TAKEBE (1719 to April 28, 1774) was a haiku poet, a novelist, a Japanese classical literature scholar, and a painter in the mid Edo period.
Ayatari TAKEBE (1719 to April 28, 1774) was a haiku poet, a novelist, a Japanese classical literature scholar, and a painter in the mid Edo period.
Ayatari TAKEBE (1719 to April 28, 1774) was a haiku poet, a novelist, a Japanese classical literature scholar, and a painter in the mid Edo period.

sen.j: 和歌和歌の歌体を好み、その復興に努めた。
sen.e: He liked the poetry style of Japanese poems, and tried for the revival.
He liked the poetry style of Japanese poems, and tried for the revival.
He liked the poetry style of Japanese poems, and tried for the revival.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 享保4年（1719年）、陸奥国弘前藩家老喜多村校尉政方と玉江との次男として、江戸に生まれ、弘前市で育った。
sen.e: In 1719, he was born in Edo as the second son of Masamichi (commissioned officer, Kita-mura Village, chief retainer, the Hirosaki Clan, Mutsu Province) and Tamae.
In 1719, he was born in Edo as the second son of Masamichi (commissioned officer, Kita-mura Village, chief retainer, the Hirosaki Clan, Mutsu Province) and Tamae.
In 1719, he was born in Edo as the second son of Masamichi (commissioned officer, Kita-mura Village, chief retainer, the Hirosaki Clan, Mutsu Province) and Tamae.

sen.j: 幼名は金吾、元服名は久域（ひさむら）。
sen.e: His childhood name was Kingo, and his name after celebrating his coming of age was Hisamura.
His childhood name was Kingo, and his name after celebrating his coming of age was Hisamura.
His childhood name was Kingo, and his name after celebrating his coming of age was Hisamura.

sen.j: 政方の母は、山鹿素行の娘であった。
sen.e: Mother of Masamichi was a daughter of Soko YAMAGA.
Mother of Masamichi was a daughter of Soko YAMAGA.
Mother of Masamichi was a daughter of Soko YAMAGA.

sen.j: 享保14年（1729年）11歳、父政方没。
sen.e: In 1729, he was 11 years old and his father Masamichi died.
In 1729, when he was 11 years old, his father Masamichi died.
In 1729, when he was 11 years old, his father Masamichi died.

sen.j: 少年期の彼は文武に励み、槍術に優れた。
sen.e: During his boyhood, he worked hard at literary and military arts, he excelled in the spearmanship.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: During his boyhood, he worked hard at literary and military arts, he excelled in the spearmanship.
During his boyhood, he worked hard at literary and military arts, he excelled in the spearmanship.

sen.j: しかし、元文3年（1738年）20歳、兄嫁との情事のため、弘前の家から追われた。
sen.e: However in 1738, he, then 20 years old, was expelled from the Hirosaki house because of the love affair with his elder sister-in-law.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However in 1738, he, then 20 years old, was expelled from the Hirosaki house because of the love affair with his elder sister-in-law.
However in 1738, he, then 20 years old, was expelled from the Hirosaki house because of the love affair with his elder sister-in-law.

sen.j: 翌々年、彼女は死んだ。
sen.e: She died 2 years later.
She died 2 years later.
She died 2 years later.

sen.j: 出家して僧『円宗』となったが、9年後、還俗した。
sen.e: He entered into priesthood, became a priest titled Enshu, but nine years later, he returned to secular life.
He entered into priesthood, became a priest titled Enshu, but nine years later, he returned to secular life.
He entered into priesthood, became a priest titled Enshu, but nine years later, he returned to secular life.

sen.j: 俳諧を志し、各地を転々としながら、その道で名を成した。
sen.e: Aiming at the seventeen-syllable verse, he established his name in the field while wandering to various places.
Pursuing the seventeen-syllable verse, he established his name in the field while wandering to various places.
Pursuing the seventeen-syllable verse, he established his name in the field while wandering to various places.

sen.j: 師は、まず蕉門十哲の志太野坡。
sen.e: His master was first Yaba SHIDA, who was one of the ten representative pupils under Basho MATSUO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: His master was first Yaba SHIDA, who was one of the ten representative pupils under Basho MATSUO.
His master was first Yaba SHIDA, who was one of the ten representative pupils under Basho MATSUO.

sen.j: ついで、伊勢派の彭城百川、和田希因、中森梅路らであった。
sen.e: Next, his teachers included Hyakusen SAKAKI of Ise school, Kiin WADA, and Umeji NAKAMORI et al.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Next, his teachers included Hyakusen SAKAKI of Ise school, Kiin WADA, and Umeji NAKAMORI et al.
Next, his teachers included Hyakusen SAKAKI of Ise school, Kiin WADA, and Umeji NAKAMORI et al.

sen.j: 俳号は、はじめ葛鼠（かっそ）、のちに、都因・涼袋・涼帒などを用いた。
sen.e: The haiku pen name was first Kasso, then later Toin, Ryotai and so on.
The haiku pen name was first Kasso, then later Toin, Ryotai and so on.
The haiku pen name was first Kasso, then later Toin, Ryotai and so on.

sen.j: 延享4年（1747年）29歳、江戸浅草に『吸露庵』を構え、俳諧の弟子をとったが、その後も旅を多くした。
sen.e: In 1747, at the age of 29, he set up 'Kyuro-an' in Asakusa of Edo, received apprentices for Haikai (seventeen-syllable verses), but afterward, he traveled much.
In 1747, at the age of 29, he set up 'Kyuro-an' in Asakusa of Edo, received apprentices for Haikai (seventeen-syllable verses), but afterward, he traveled much.
In 1747, at the age of 29, he set up 'Kyuro-an' in Asakusa of Edo, received apprentices for Haikai (seventeen-syllable verses), but afterward, he traveled much.

sen.j: 寛延2年（1749年）門人らの援助を得て上方へおもむき。
sen.e: In 1749, he obtained assistance from his disciples The pupils' help, and he proceeded up to Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area).
In 1749, thanks to his pupils' help, and he proceeded up to Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area).
In 1749, thanks to his pupils' help, and he proceeded up to Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area).

sen.j: 翌年長崎に寄寓して、熊代熊斐と石崎元徳に、約半年画を学んだ。
sen.e: The next year, he temporarily stayed in Nagasaki, and studied painting from Yuhi KUMASHIRO and Gentoku ISHIZAKI for about half a year.
The next year, he temporarily stayed in Nagasaki, and studied painting from Yuhi KUMASHIRO and Gentoku ISHIZAKI for about half a year.
The next year, he temporarily stayed in Nagasaki, and studied painting from Yuhi KUMASHIRO and Gentoku ISHIZAKI for about half a year.

sen.j: 宝暦元年（1751年）、大阪に留まり画業で暮らし、翌年江戸へ帰った。
sen.e: In 1751, he stayed in Osaka, earned a living by painting, and returned to Edo region the next year.
In 1751, he stayed in Osaka, earned a living by painting, and returned to Edo region the next year.
In 1751, he stayed in Osaka, earned a living by painting, and returned to Edo region the next year.

sen.j: 宝暦3年（1753年）35歳、母の勧めで、中津藩主奥平昌敦に仕えた。
sen.e: In 1753, at the age of 35, he served Masaatsu OKUDAIRA, the feudal lord of Nakatsu clan, as recommended by his mother.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1753, at the age of 35, he served Masaatsu OKUDAIRA, the feudal lord of Nakatsu clan, as recommended by his mother.
In 1753, at the age of 35, he served Masaatsu OKUDAIRA, the feudal lord of Nakatsu clan, as recommended by his mother.

sen.j: 翌年、藩命により、ふたたび長崎で約1年半、費漢源に山水画、李用雲に墨竹図を学んだ。
sen.e: The next year, as commanded by the clan, he stayed in Nagasaki again for about one and a half years, and studied landscape picture under Hikangen and Bamboo Groves in ink under Liyoun.
sen.cmt: 費漢源と李用雲の読み方は不明。一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The next year, as commanded by the clan, he stayed in Nagasaki again for about one and a half years, and studied landscape picture under Hikangen and Bamboo Groves in ink under Liyoun.
The next year, as commanded by the clan, he stayed in Nagasaki again for about one and a half years, and studied landscape picture under Hikangen and Bamboo Groves in ink under Liyoun.

sen.j: 目を患ったためか濃密な彩色花鳥画より淡雅な筆致を好むようになる。
sen.e: Probably because of his illness of eyes, he preferred a touch of faint brushwork to dense coloring flower and bird picture.
Probably because of his illness of eyes, he preferred a touch of faint brushwork to dense coloring flower and bird picture.
Probably because of his illness of eyes, he preferred a touch of faint brushwork to dense coloring flower and bird picture.

sen.j: 画家としての号は、孟喬（うきょう）・毛倫・建綾岱・建長江・寒葉斎などであった。
sen.e: As the painter, he used pen names such as Ukyo, Morin, Kenryotai, Kenchoe, and Kanyosai.
As the painter, he used pen names such as Ukyo, Morin, Kenryotai, Kenchoe, and Kanyosai.
As the painter, he used pen names such as Ukyo, Morin, Kenryotai, Kenchoe, and Kanyosai.

sen.j: 宝暦7年（1757年）39歳、遊女の紫苑（号、伎都）と結婚した。
sen.e: In 1757, at the age of 39, he got married with the prostitute Shien (titled Gito).
In 1757, at the age of 39, he got married with the prostitute Shien (titled Gito).
In 1757, at the age of 39, he got married with the prostitute Shien (titled Gito).

sen.j: 翌年中津藩を辞した。
sen.e: The next year, he left the Nakatsu clan.
The next year, he left the Nakatsu clan.
The next year, he left the Nakatsu clan.

sen.j: 宝暦12年（1762年）44歳、『寒葉斎画譜』を刊行。
sen.e: In 1762, at the age of 44, he published "Kanyosai Gakuhu" (Picture Collection in the Cold Leave Study).
In 1762, at the age of 44, he published "Kanyosai Gakuhu" (collection of his pictures).
sen.cmt: 寒葉斎は画号のため、訳出不要と判断しました。
sen.e: In 1762, at the age of 44, he published "Kanyosai Gakuhu" (collection of his pictures).

sen.j: 宝暦13年（1763年）45歳、和歌和歌の歌体を提唱し、『綾足』の号を用いた。
sen.e: In 1763, at the age of 45, he promoted the poetry style of Japanese poems and used the pen name "Ryosoku".
In 1763, at the age of 45, he promoted the poetry style of Japanese poems and used the pen name "Ayatari".
sen.cmt: 名前『綾足』の読みがりょうそくになっている
sen.e: In 1763, at the age of 45, he promoted the poetry style of Japanese poems and used the pen name "Ayatari".

sen.j: 賀茂真淵に入門した。
sen.e: He became a disciple of KAMO no Mabuchi.
He became a disciple of KAMO no Mabuchi.
He became a disciple of KAMO no Mabuchi.

sen.j: 明和3年（1766年）、歌道の冷泉家に入門した。
sen.e: In 1766, he became a disciple of the Reizei family of tanka poetry.
In 1766, he became a disciple of the Reizei family of tanka poetry.
In 1766, he became a disciple of the Reizei family of tanka poetry.

sen.j: 明和5年、初めての小説『西山物語』を上梓した。
sen.e: In 1768, he published his first novel "The Tales of Nishiyama".
In 1768, he published his first novel "The Tales of Nishiyama".
In 1768, he published his first novel "The Tales of Nishiyama".

sen.j: 京都に住み、片歌と国学とを講義した。
sen.e: He lived in Kyoto, and lectured on Katauta (style of poetry) and Japanese classical literature.
He lived in Kyoto, and lectured on Katauta (style of poetry) and Japanese classical literature.
He lived in Kyoto, and lectured on Katauta (style of poetry) and Japanese classical literature.

sen.j: この頃から浅草出身の僧侶金龍道人と交友を深める。
sen.e: From that period, he deepened his friendship with Kinryu Donin, who was a Buddhist monk from Asakusa.
From that period, he deepened his friendship with Kinryu Donin, who was a Buddhist monk from Asakusa.
From that period, he deepened his friendship with Kinryu Donin, who was a Buddhist monk from Asakusa.

sen.j: 明和7年（1770年）52歳、片歌の祖と考えたヤマトタケルの能褒野王塚古墳前に、片歌碑を建てた。
sen.e: In 1770, at the age of 52, he built a monument in front of the Nobono Ouzuka Old Tomb of Yamato Takeru, who was regarded as the founder of Katauta (style of poetry).
In 1770, at the age of 52, he built a monument in front of the Nobono Ouzuka Old Tomb of Yamato Takeru, who was regarded as the founder of Katauta (style of poetry).
In 1770, at the age of 52, he built a monument in front of the Nobono Ouzuka Old Tomb of Yamato Takeru, who was regarded as the founder of Katauta (style of poetry).

sen.j: 花山院常雅から『片歌道守』の称号を得た。
sen.e: He was awarded the title of "Katauta no Chimori" from Tsunemasa KAZANIN.
He was awarded the title of "Katauta no Chimori" from Tsunemasa KAZANIN.
He was awarded the title of "Katauta no Chimori" from Tsunemasa KAZANIN.

sen.j: 京都で万葉集や古今集を講義した。
sen.e: He lectured on Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and Kokinshu (Collection of Ancient and Modern) in Kyoto.
He lectured on Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and Kokinshu (Collection of Ancient and Modern) in Kyoto.
He lectured on Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) and Kokinshu (Collection of Ancient and Modern) in Kyoto.

sen.j: 安永2年（1773年）55歳、旅行中に病み、翌安永3年（1774年）、江戸の仮寓に没し、向島弘福寺に葬った。
sen.e: In 1773, at the age of 55, he got sick while traveling, and in 1774, he died in his temporary mansion in Edo, and his body was buried in Mukaishima Kofuku-ji Temple.
In 1773, at the age of 55, he got sick while traveling, and in 1774, he died in his temporary mansion in Edo, and his body was buried in Mukaishima Kofuku-ji Temple.
In 1773, at the age of 55, he got sick while traveling, and in 1774, he died in his temporary mansion in Edo, and his body was buried in Mukaishima Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 『知足院即心是空居士』。
sen.e: Chisoku-in Sokushin Zeku Kyoshi (a lay Buddhist of Empty Heart in Chisoku-in Temple)
Chisoku-in Sokushin Zeku Kyoshi (a lay Buddhist of Empty Heart in Chisoku-in Temple)
Chisoku-in Sokushin Zeku Kyoshi (a lay Buddhist of Empty Heart in Chisoku-in Temple)

sen.j: 墓碑は現存しない。
sen.e: His tombstone is not existing any more.
His tombstone is not existing any more.
His tombstone is not existing any more.

sen.j: 安永5年（1776年）、母玉江、没。
sen.e: In 1776, his mother Tamae died.
In 1776, his mother Tamae died.
In 1776, his mother Tamae died.
